title: Double slit - y-max for different lambda and m

content.question: Monochromatic light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>X</mi></msub></mstyle></math> passes through two closely-spaced, parallel slits, producing an interference pattern on a screen some distance away from the slits. The distance from the central maximum to the center of the first-order maximum is <math alttext="s sub 1 comma X, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>s</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>. Next, monochromatic light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda sub Y equals three halves lambda sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>Y</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>X</mi></msub></mstyle></math> passes through the same slits and produces an interference pattern on the same screen. In the new pattern, the distance from the central maximum to the center of the second-order maximum is <math alttext="s sub 2 comma Y, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>s</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="s sub 2 comma Y, end sub, to s sub 1 comma X, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>s</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>Y</mi></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math>? Assume that the light forming both interference patterns is directed at small angles from the incident light direction.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
